III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff twist Youth A's arm behind his back causing pain. They bend
Youth A's wrist backwards. One of the men went in Youth A's
room and punched him in his ribs.
2

Investigation This complaint was received on 4/2/23 and jointly investigated
with the Government Worker. The complaint noted the following:
Youth A (12) resides at Christ Child House. Two young African
American males that work afternoon and evening twist Youth A's
arm behind his back causing pain. They bend his wrist
backwards. One of the men went into his room and punched him
in his ribs. Unknown if marks and bruises. Date is unknown.
Youth A has lost over 60 lbs. over the past year, and he has black
rings under his eyes.
The referral source was spoken with on 4/3/23 via the phone.
The referral source confirmed the allegations and identified herself
as Youth A's previous foster parent. The referral source indicated
Youth A is fearful of his placement and she is concerned about his
drastic weight loss.
Youth A was interviewed by the Government Worker on 4/5/23 at
school. Youth A refused to talk and only provided the names of
the staff who allegedly bend his wrists backwards and the man
who punched him in his ribs. Youth A alleged Youth Specialist 1
bends his arm and wrist back and Youth Specialist 2 punched him
in the ribs in his room. He refused to discuss food/weight issues.
Youth A alleged Youth Specialist 2 punched him in the stomach in
his room on 2/7/23. The allegation was investigated in Special
Investigation 2023C0000239. There were no violations
established.
A second interview with Youth A was attempted on 4/18/23 at the
facility in collaboration with the Government Worker. Youth A
refused to enter the room. Staff attempted to encourage him to
come in and talk, but he refused to enter the room and stood with
his back to the room.
I interviewed Youth Specialist 1 at the facility on 4/18/23, jointly
with the Government Worker. Youth Specialist 1 reported he does
not recall ever bending Youth A's arm or wrist back. He denied
knowledge of any staff bending Youth A's arm or wrists back.
Youth Specialist 1 reported he can't remember the last time he
touched Youth A and indicated they are not allowed to horseplay
with any of the youth. Youth Specialist 1 reported he was written
up for horseplay with Youth A in March. Youth Specialist 1
reported he has not been in Youth A's room alone with him and he
has not seen any staff members in Youth A's room with him alone.
Youth Specialist 1 denied punching Youth A in the ribs in his
room. He denied any knowledge of a staff member punching
3

Youth A in the ribs. Youth Specialist 1 reported Youth A makes a
lot of allegations and when he does, he reports them to the
Residential Director.
Youth Specialist 2 was interviewed at the facility on 4/18/23, jointly
with the Government Worker. Youth Specialist 2 denied bending
youth A's arms or wrist back. He denied punching Youth A in the
ribs in his bedroom. Youth Specialist 2 denied any incidents of
restraint with Youth A or horseplay. Youth Specialist 2 reported he
has never been in Youth A's bedroom alone and if they enter a
youth's bedroom, they must have a second staff as a witness.
Youth Specialist 2 reported having no knowledge of any staff
twisting or bending Youth A's arm back or punching Youth A in the
ribs. Youth Specialist 2 reported he has no disciplinary actions
from involvement with Youth A.
The Residential Director was interviewed jointly with the
Government Worker on 4/18/23. Residential Director reported
Youth A has not had any restraints in the past 30 days and they
try not to restrain Youth A as he doesn't like to be touched.
Residential Director reported Youth A refuses to do many
activities. He refused to have his blood drawn so had to be taken
off one of his medications due to it requiring blood draws to
ensure safe levels of the medication. Youth A refused his well-
child examination last week by refusing to get into the car to go to
the appointment. Residential Director reported she watched
footage from the last time Youth Specialist 1 and Youth Specialist
2 worked together and Youth Specialist 1 and 2 never entered
Youth A's room and she never saw Youth Specialist 1 or 2 twist or
bend Youth A's arms.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed at the facility on 4/18/23 jointly with
the Government Worker. Supervisor 1 reported he supervises
Youth Worker 1, and he is not aware of any issues with Youth
Worker 1 twisting or bending Youth A's wrists or punching him in
the ribs. Supervisor 1 reported that they have had to talk with staff
about being mindful about horseplaying. Supervisor 1 reported
Youth Worker 2 used to rough house, but he has never seen
Youth Worker 2 do anything that concerns him.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed at the facility on 4/18/23, jointly with
the Government Worker Supervisor 2 supervises second shift
staff. Supervisor 2 reported he has had to address horseplay with
all staff. Supervisor 2 reported an incident where Youth Worker 2
and a youth were pulling on each other shirts in a playful way that
was addressed. Supervisor 2 did not report any concerns with
4

Youth Worker 1 and the youth except for horseplaying which was
addressed with all the staff at a staff meeting.
Youth B was interviewed at the facility on 4/18/23 jointly with the
Government Worker. Youth B reported he has been living at
Christ Child House for the past two months and it is "decent". He
likes that they go on outings and dislikes they can't have electronic
devices. Youth B reported he likes all the staff and that the staff
are not allowed to horseplay with them. Youth B denied
experiencing any horseplay with staff or seeing any horseplay
between staff and youth. Youth B reported he feels safe at the
facility. Youth B reported that Youth A cries about staff and says
they hurt him. Youth B denied seeing staff hurt Youth A.
Documentation Reviewed:
Youth Specialist 1’s behavior discipline report from 3/6/23-second
warning for horseplay. Youth Specialist 1 was seen on video
engaging in horseplay with Youth A by tripping him.
Youth Specialist 2’s behavior discipline report dated 10/27/22.
Youth Specialist 2 was given a verbal warning with written
confirmation for roughhousing with a resident by shoving him into
the bathroom.
Youth Specialist 2 received a verbal warning with written
confirmation on 1/18/23 for having an inappropriate sexual
conversation with a coworker about another coworker within
earshot of a resident.
There are no incident reports for the alleged incidents.
There is no video footage of Youth A being punched in the ribs as
there are no cameras in the youth bedrooms.
Analysis Based upon the interviews there is no evidence that supports
Youth A's arms were twisted behind his back by staff or that his
wrists were bend backwards. There is no evidence that supports
Youth A was punched in the stomach by staff in his room.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health Services; policies and procedures.
Section
Description (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A has lost over 60 lbs. in the past year and has black rings
under his eyes. Youth A's health is not being monitored and
screened appropriately.
Investigation I spoke with Youth A's previous foster mother on 4/3/23. Youth A's
previous foster mother reported she recently visited with Youth A
and is very concerned about Youth A's significant weight loss.
She reported Youth A's clothes hang off of him and that he has
dark circles under his eyes. She reported he told her he does not
like the food at the facility and he likes to eat at school. She
reported when she took him out for a visit, he did eat chicken
strips and ice cream.
The foster care worker and supervisor were contacted via email
on 4/3/23. The foster care worker reported she sees Youth A
monthly and has noticed a significant weight loss. The foster care
worker reported Youth A had a medication change to assist with
his appetite and Youth A reports he doesn't like the food at the
facility but eats at school. The foster care worker reported Youth A
has no medical conditions known to cause the weight loss. The
foster care worker reported that Youth A's older sister has an
eating disorder and Youth A reportedly told his sister to throw up
her food, so she didn't get fat like their parents.
Documentation Reviewed:
Youth A’s last physical dated 5/2/22. Youth A weighed 156 lbs.

Youth A has lost 43 lbs. and currently weighs 110.2 lbs. The
average weight for a 12-year-old boy falls between 67-130 lbs.
Youth A stands 61 inches tall and the average height for a 12 year
old boy is 54 to 63 inches.
I interviewed the facility's Nurse via the phone on 4/20/23 jointly
with the Government Worker. The Nurse reported she sees the
youth at the facility approximately once a week. She records and
monitors the children's height, weight, blood pressure, heart rate,
and pulse oxygen. The Nurse reported that Youth A has had a
"serious weight loss" while at the facility. She reported she
encourages Youth A to eat, and he frequently says the food is
nasty at the facility. She reported on 4/5/23 Youth A saw the
psychiatrist and his medication was adjusted to help with his
appetite. Youth A is reportedly starting to eat more frequently
and has had a small weight gain in the past month. The Nurse
reported she is responsible to make referrals for the youth's
medical needs if she feels they need additional services or
assessments. She has scheduled Youth A with a dietitian but had
not consider having him assessed for an eating disorder. The
Nurse reported that Youth A has not dropped into a low weight
percentile even though he has had a significant weight loss. The
Nurse did not feel Youth A needed to see a doctor about his rapid
weight loss or that he has reached an unhealthy weight. Youth A
is schedule to have his well child exam tomorrow. Youth a refused
to attend his well child exam earlier in the month indicating he
doesn't like doctors or getting shots.
Youth A's therapist is currently out on FLMA, and the Clinical
Director was able to provide a statement regarding Youth A's
therapeutic services on 4/21/23. Her statement indicated Youth A
and his Therapist discuss healthy body image, healthy diet and
lifestyle in therapy. Youth A denies having an eating disorder and
expresses that he just prefers certain foods over others. Youth
A's Therapist makes sure to have some of his favorite snacks in
her office for sessions. The foster care worker recently informed
us that his sister has an eating disorder – she is bulimic and
binges and purges. We do not have any concerns that Youth A
7

has bulimia. Youth A appears to be a very picky eater and very
stubborn. Youth A is diagnosed with PTSD, ADHD and ODD. He
takes two medications for ADHD and three medications for mood
stabilization.
The Residential Director reported Youth A refuses to do many
activities. He refused to have his blood drawn so had to be taken
off one of his medications due to it requiring blood draws to
ensure safe levels of the medication in his system. Youth A
refused his well-child examination last week refusing to get into
the car to go to the appointment. The Residential Director reported
she is unsure how to address this as they cannot make the youth
go to the doctor or get in the car. The Residential Director
reported she does not want to make a big deal about food and
eating as she knows this could make the issue worse. They
provide the youth with meals and snacks and offer him alternative
options should he not like what is being served. The Residential
Director reported Youth A has lost about 50 lbs. since being at
Christ Child House and she has noticed he has dark circles
around his eyes. Youth A is reportedly a picky eater and refuses
to eat frequently. The facility has recently begun documenting
what he eats and refuses at each meal. The nurse keeps a
running log of Youth A's weight.
I interviewed Youth Specialist 1 and 2, Supervisors 1 and 2 and
Youth B at the facility on 4/18/23, jointly with the Government
Worker. All staff h interviewed reported Youth A is a picky eater
and that he came to the facility chuncky and has had a significant
weight loss. The staff reported they have begun to track and log
the food Youth A eats and refuses each day. The staff reported
Youth A is offered Ensure and several food options at mealtime.
The staff all reported they monitor Youth A after meals to ensure
he is not purging his food and they do not believe that he is
purging.
Youth A was interviewed briefly by the Government Worker at
school on 4/5/23 and he refused to discuss food/weight issues. A
second interview was attempted with Youth A on 4/18/23 at the
facility jointly with the Government Worker. Youth A refused to
meet or be interviewed.
Analysis Based upon interviews there is no evidence that supports Youth
A's health is not being monitored and assessed appropriately.
Youth A's health is being monitored and assessed weekly by the
on-staff Nurse. According to the Nurse Youth A has lost a
significant amount of weight, but he has not dropped below the
8

50% percentile in weight and the Nurse does not feel Youth A has
reached an unhealthy weight range. The nurse has set up Youth A
to see a dietitian. The facility has responded and continues to
respond to youth's weight loss by tracking his food intake,
encouraging and having Ensure for him, offering food options,
keeping foods he likes on hand, and weighing him monthly since
admission. The nurse and therapist encourage him to eat and try
new foods and to attend his doctor appointments.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE: It is recommended that Youth A
have a medical/psychiatrist evaluation to specifically rule out an
eating disorder. The facility should provide Youth A's historical
weight chart, daily food intake log and food refusals to all future
doctor and psychiatric appointments. It is recommended the
facility solicit assistance from youth's foster care worker to
facilitate his attendance at all scheduled doctor appointments.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
